questions.question: Explain why inverse kinematics may have multiple solutions. Give a physical example.
questions.answer_template: Inverse kinematics can have multiple solutions because [EXPLANATION]. A physical example is [EXAMPLE].

key_points: The same end-effector position can be reached through different joint angle combinations
For a 2-link planar arm, there are typically two solutions: elbow-up and elbow-down configurations
The arm can fold in different ways to reach the same point
expected_answer.example: A 2-DOF planar arm with links L1 and L2 trying to reach a point at distance R from origin where |L1-L2| < R < L1+L2. The elbow-up solution has the second joint angle positive (curving upward), while elbow-down has it negative (curving downward). Both reach the same Cartesian position.

rubric.excellent_2pts: Explains the mathematical reason (redundancy in joint space) and provides a clear physical example with specific reference to elbow-up/elbow-down configurations
rubric.proficient_1pt: Mentions multiple solutions exist but may not fully explain why, or provides example without clear reasoning
rubric.beginning_0pts: Does not address the question or provides incorrect information about IK solutions

questions.question: Differentiate between joint space and workspace. Why is this distinction important for robot programming?
questions.answer_template: Joint space is [DEFINITION], while workspace is [DEFINITION]. The distinction is important because [REASON].

key_points: Joint space: the space of joint angles/positions (q1, q2, ..., qn)
Workspace: the set of all reachable end-effector positions and orientations in Cartesian space
Important because robots are controlled in joint space but tasks are specified in Cartesian space
Trajectory planning must convert between these spaces (IK and FK)

rubric.excellent_2pts: Clearly defines both spaces, explains the dimensional difference, and articulates why the distinction matters for robot control and trajectory planning
rubric.proficient_1pt: Defines both spaces but may not fully explain the practical importance or makes minor errors in definition
rubric.beginning_0pts: Confuses the concepts or cannot differentiate between them

questions.question: Describe the canonical form of robot manipulator dynamics: M(q)q̈ + C(q, q̇)q̇ + g(q) = τ. What does each term represent?
questions.answer_template: The equation represents [OVERVIEW]. M(q) is [M], C(q, q̇) is [C], and g(q) is [G].

key_points: M(q): Mass/inertia matrix - depends on configuration, describes how joint accelerations relate to torques
C(q, q̇): Coriolis and centrifugal terms - depends on velocities, captures coupling between joints during motion
g(q): Gravity vector - configuration-dependent, represents torque required to counteract gravity
τ: Joint torques/forces - the control inputs

rubric.excellent_2pts: Correctly identifies all four terms with clear physical interpretations, demonstrates understanding of configuration-dependent nature
rubric.proficient_1pt: Identifies most terms correctly but may have minor confusion about physical meaning
rubric.beginning_0pts: Cannot identify the terms or provides incorrect interpretations
